newsArray.title: Big Bash League: Bail falls on its own during Renegades-Heat tie, leaves batter confused
creator: FirstCricket Staff
newsArray.description: Big Bash League: Bail falls on its own during Renegades-Heat tie, leaves batter confused
newsArray.content: Weird moments are often seen on a cricket field â€“ from playerâ€™s antics, animals invading the pitch, or the ball hitting the stumps but keeping the bails intact.Another similar incident was seen in the Big Bash League round-robin match as the bails were dislodged without anything hitting the stumps during Melbourne Renegadesâ€™ tie against Brisbane Heat at the Cazalyâ€™s Stadium in Cairns on Thursday.Interestingly, a day earlier, Indiaâ€™s Shreyas Iyer earned a lifeline in the Test match against Bangladesh as the ball hit the stumps after he missed the line, but the bails remained intact and he went on to play.The incident happened when Renegades skipper Nic Maddinson was facing Mark Steketee in the ninth over. Maddinson tried to play a pull shot and had his front foot going back toward the stumps in the process. The players, including the batter, and commentators thought of it to be a hit wicket and Maddinson started walking back to the dugout.However, the replays suggested that he did not hit the stumps. The bail had fallen due to wind and he was not even close to the stumps.Watch the video:What on earth???Looks like the windâ€™s knocked the bail off! Maddinson stays safe ğŸ˜…@KFCAustralia #BucketMoment #BBL12 pic.twitter.com/sboxGvIewAâ€” KFC Big Bash League (@BBL) December 15, 2022 The third umpire confirmed the scene and Maddinson went on to bat further. The southpaw was on 42 when the incident happened, but went on to score 87 from 49 deliveries. His knock included 10 boundaries and three maximums.His innings also proved to be pivotal in Renegadesâ€™ 22 runs win over Brisbane Heat and he was awarded the player of the match award.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

newsArray.title: ICC launches maiden U-19 Women's T20 World Cup in South Africa
creator: Sentinel Digital Desk
newsArray.description: The International Cricket Council (ICC) launched the inaugural ICC U-19 Women's T20 World Cup here, with one month to go until the first ball is bowled in the tournament.
newsArray.content: BENONI: The International Cricket Council (ICC) launched the inaugural ICC U-19 Women's T20 World Cup here on Wednesday, with one month to go until the first ball is bowled in the tournament.The event which is a first of its kind in world cricket will take place from January 14 to 29, 2023 and will see the future stars of the women's game compete in 41 matches played across four venues in Benoni and Potchefstroom in 16 days of competitive cricket. The 16 teams in the fray include Indonesia and Rwanda, who will feature in an ICC World Cup for the first time ever. Eleven full member nations gained automatic entry in this historic edition: Australia, Bangladesh, England, India, Ireland, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, the West Indies and Zimbabwe. Scotland, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States of America (USA) join Indonesia and Rwanda to take the remaining five slots, representing each of the ICC's five regions. The teams will be divided into groups of four. Australia are in group A along with Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and USA while Group B features England, Pakistan, Rwanda and Zimbabwe. New Zealand, Ireland, Indonesia and the West Indies complete the group C, with India, Scotland, South Africa and the UAE featuring in Group D. At the competition launch, former Proteas women's cricketer and South African Olympic javelin silver medallist, Sunette Viljoen, was unveiled as the ICC U19 Women's T20 World Cup Ambassador. She was joined by the Member of the Executive Council of Gauteng Sports, Arts & Culture, Morakane Mosupyoe. The other notable guests included Cricket South Africa Board Member and LOC Chair, Muditambi Ravele, CSA CEO, Pholetsi Moseki, UNICEF South Africa Chief of Communications & Partnerships, Toby Fricker and South Africa women's team players, Sinalo Jafta and Raisibe Ntozakhe. "This is a watershed moment for women's cricket in South Africa and for the game in our country. To host one ICC event in a year is cause for great celebration, but to claim two in such quick succession is beyond our wildest dreams," Tournament Director Sivuyile Mqingwana said in an ICC media statement. newsArray.title: Pro Kabaddi League 2022: Bengaluru Bulls coach Randhir Singh hopes for strong defensive show
creator: FP Sports
newsArray.description: Pro Kabaddi League 2022: Bengaluru Bulls coach Randhir Singh hopes for strong defensive show
newsArray.content: Sports Pro Kabaddi League 2022: Bengaluru Bulls coach Randhir Singh hopes for strong defensive show Jaipur Pink Panthers will take on Bengaluru Bulls in the first Pro Kabaddi League semi-final. The other will see Puneri Paltan face Tamil Thalaivas FP Sports December 15, 2022 16:56:44 IST Randhir Singh, coach of Bengaluru Bulls, speaks to his team during a Pro Kabaddi League game. Image: Pro Kabaddi Pro Kabaddi League semi-finals: The Bengaluru Bulls put on a show for their fans in Eliminator 1, decimating Dabang Delhi by a scoreline of 56-24, to book their spot in the Pro Kabaddi semi-final. Raiders Vikash Kandola and Bharat were in top form, and Coach Randhir Singh was understandably delighted as this was also the first time the Bengaluru Bulls had defeated Dabang Delhi side in the playoff stages. â€œThe game against the Dabang Delhi KC side has to be the most impressive game for me in this season. We have history against Dabang Delhi team, so this win was even sweeter for us,â€ the coach said. Speaking on what he needs the team to do going ahead, Randhir Singh said, â€œIf the defensive unit can work well and put up a strong show, then the Bengaluru Bulls will do well, because my raiders are in form, Bharat, Vikash and Neeraj. In the Semi-Final, the strategy is always different and we will do our best against the Jaipur Pink Panthers, who are a solid team too.â€ Going into the Semi-Final, the Tamil Thalaivasâ€™ coach Ashan Kumar has complete faith in his squad, and said, â€œThe team is in a good place and we will continue to work on our tactics, keep clarity in our roles, and work in a way that our coordination is not disturbed as well. We will continue to discuss these essential aspects, and if we can execute our plans well, there is no doubt we will do well against Puneri Paltan.â€ Pro Kabaddi semi-final fixtures: Jaipur Pink Panthers vs Bengaluru Bulls Puneri Paltan vs Tamil Thalaivas Read all the Latest News , Trending News , Cricket News , Bollywood News , India News and Entertainment News here. Follow us on Facebook , Twitter and Instagram . Updated Date: December 15, 2022 16:56:44 IST TAGS: Kabaddi Pkl 2022 Pro Kabaddi League 2022

newsArray.title: T20 World Cup came at a perfect time for us to showcase Melbourne, says Visit Victoria CEO Brendan McClements
creator: Sahil Malhotra
newsArray.description: T20 World Cup came at a perfect time for us to showcase Melbourne, says Visit Victoria CEO Brendan McClements
newsArray.content: Tourism sector was one of the worst hit in Australia during COVID-19 as the country locked its borders and imposed a strict and lengthy lockdown. Slowly, but surely, the borders have reopened and tourism activities have returned to full swing.Sports continues to play a major role in driving tourism back to Australia. Melbourne, Victoria in particular. A well-contested T20 World Cup, featuring the blockbuster India-Pakistan clash at the MCG, has played its part and now itâ€™s over to the upcoming Australian Open and the Australian Grand Prix to sustain the momentum.In an exclusive chat with Firstpost.com, Visit Victoriaâ€™s CEO Brendan McClements talks about the challenge of bringing people back to Melbourne and Victoria and the road ahead. Excerpts:How difficult was it getting people back to Australia?We obviously went through challenging time but this whole year we have been giving people reasons to come back to Melbourne and Victoria. Cricket World Cup was there, we had tennis at start of the year. So we have given people reasons to drop that reluctance. I think aviation capacity is the biggest challenge for now. Flights are full and itâ€™s difficult to get flights to Australia. The big challenge right now is not people wanting to come here, itâ€™s about people not being able to get on a plane to get here.Once you are here, you obviously have enough reasons to be interested.Oh yeah. What we have seen there is a great appetite among people to travel. As soon as they travel, they want to travel again. We are confident that if we can deal with those capacity issues, we will see a fantastic future.Cricket World Cup couldnâ€™t have been timed better for revival of tourism in Australia, right?Cricket World Cup came at a perfect time for us to showcase Melbourne and Victoria to the world, to India in particular. And we have seen a fantastic response. Tens of thousands of Indians have travelled for the World Cup, so as the world comes back to us, India is very important part of our relationship. And this was an ideal starting point for us to reintroduce Melbourne and Victoria to the market of people.There is a lot of cultural diversity on display in Melbourne. You think that could help play a part when you look at reviving tourism in the country overall?We are proud of the multicultural nature of Melbourne. More than 200,000 Indians chose to make Melbourne their home. Really strong connections people to people here. So many students prefer to study here, so I think itâ€™s a really embracing place. So there can be no place better than Melbourne to start your journey in Australia.And thereâ€™s more to see in Melbourne than just the rich sporting culture.Absolutely yes. We are proud of our sporting culture but we also have a wonderful food culture, art culture and we are close to natural wildlife. So If you want to come to a place which has great urban experience and also experience Australian kangaroos, which is not far away, then Melbourne is the place for you. For Indian tourists, itâ€™s the perfect location. So come to Melbourne is my message for everyone out there.(The writer was in Melbourne on invite of Visit Victoria)Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

newsArray.title: First Test: Bangladesh slip to 37/2 at tea as India take control
creator: Post News Network
newsArray.description: Chattogram: Pace duo of Mohammed Siraj and Umesh Yadav reduced Bangladesh to 37 for 2 at tea after a stunning lower-order fightback helped India take control of the opening Test against Bangladesh here Thursday. Siraj struck on the very first ball when he induced an edge off lefthander Najmul Hossain Shanto with an away-going delivery. [â€¦]
newsArray.content: First Test: Bangladesh slip to 37/2 at tea as India take control PTI Updated: December 15th, 2022, 15:28 IST in Sports 0 Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on WhatsApp Share on Linkedin Chattogram: Pace duo of Mohammed Siraj and Umesh Yadav reduced Bangladesh to 37 for 2 at tea after a stunning lower-order fightback helped India take control of the opening Test against Bangladesh here Thursday. Siraj struck on the very first ball when he induced an edge off lefthander Najmul Hossain Shanto with an away-going delivery. Leading the pace department in absence of Mohammed Shami and Jasprit Bumrah, Yadav then reduced Bangladesh to 5 for 2 inside the fourth over after inducing an inside edge off Yasir Ali, who was playing away from his body. But thereafter Litton Das calmed things down with his fluent drives and remained unbeaten on 24 off 26 balls. At the break, Das and Zakir Hasan (9) were in the middle with Bangladesh trailing India by 367 runs with eight wickets in hand. The opening session was all about Ravichandran Ashwin (58 off 113 balls, 2Ã—4, 2Ã—6) and Kuldeep Yadav, who made a perfect case for him as an allrounder in absence of Ravindra Jadeja, with a career-best 40 (114b; 5Ã—4). Playing his first Test after more than 22 months, Kuldeep extended splendid support to Ashwin as the duo frustrated Bangladesh with an 87-run partnership for the eighth wicket. The 28-year-old Kuldeep, who has a century and six fifties averaging 22-plus in first-class cricket, got off the mark after 18 balls as he looked solid with his defence. His slog sweep and reverse sweep shots also caught the attention. Ashwin, who has five Test centuries including four against the West Indies, showed a lot of composure and maturity en route to his 13th Test half-century. The duo hardly took a foot wrong pushing India past the 400-mark after the visitors resumed the day at 278 for 6 and lost overnight batter Shreyas Iyer (86) with the addition of just four runs to his total. Having batted India out of a tricky spot on an opening day, Iyer once again failed to get to a well-deserved hundred and got out with an addition of just four runs to his overnight total. Bangladesh skipper Shakib Al Hasan mostly employed his star spinner Mehidy Hasan Miraz to go in tandem with pacer Khaled Ahmed but Ashwin hardly looked in any trouble. He made his intentions clear stepping down to Mehidy for a six. Luck also favoured Ashwin when he survived an â€˜umpireâ€™s callâ€™ after left-arm spinner Taijul Islam had him trapped in front of the leg stump when he was on 34. That pace spearhead Ebadot Hossain was taken out of the attack after his impressive spell of 4-1-7-1 in the morning also helped the Indian cause. Kuldeep also oozed confidence as Ashwin was happy to take singles and give him the strike. newsArray.title: 'My debut was toughest day of my life': Naseem Shah opens up on mother's death before international debut
creator: FP Trending
newsArray.description: 'My debut was toughest day of my life': Naseem Shah opens up on mother's death before international debut
newsArray.content: Cricket 'My debut was toughest day of my life': Naseem Shah opens up on mother's death before international debut Naseem Shah wanted her mother to watch him playing on his debut, but the team management informed him in the morning that his mother was no more. FP Trending December 15th, 2022 14:38:55 IST Naseem Shah shared his debut struggle during the Pakistan vs England Test series. AP Pakistan pacer Naseem Shah has been one the best finds for their team in recent years. He made his international debut at the age of 16 and has been one of the main bowlers for the Men in Green since then. But it has not been an easy ride for the young pacer. Naseem Shah has gone through some tough times, with the hardest being his motherâ€™s demise just one day before his international debut. Recently, Naseem Shah opened up about the incident during a chat with Nasser Hussain for Sky Sports Cricket . Naseem stated that while he was â€œtoo attachedâ€ to his mother, he had moved to Lahore to pursue his dream of playing cricket. A day before his maiden appearance for the Men in Green in Australia, he talked to his mother and asked her to â€œwatch the game tomorrowâ€ because he would be playing. Naseemâ€™s mother was overjoyed and said she would come to Lahore and watch him play. But tragedy struck. When Naseem woke up, the management informed the pacer that his mother had passed away. Despite his loss, the youngster soon made his debut Test appearance against Australia in Brisbane and picked up David Warnerâ€™s wicket. Naseem also broke his silence about the struggles he endured after he started his career. â€œFor the next six-to-eight months, I struggled so much. No one thinks about whatâ€™s going on inside you. I used to have a lot of medicines, I saw my mom everywhere. I used to think about her a lot,â€ Naseem said. He also spoke about the expectations he had to live up to. â€œWhenever you play for Pakistan, everyone expects performances from you. I had a lot of injuries during that time as well, so it was a tough time. I learned from it, though. Iâ€™m stronger now. My debut was the toughest day of my life. I can manage when Iâ€™m not performing well now, because I know how tough it was,â€ he added. The Rawalpindi Test between Pakistan and England was another opportunity for the speedster to showcase his talent and Naseem did not disappoint his fans. He took 5 wickets in the fixture, with Liam Livingstone, Harry Brooks, and English skipper Ben Stokes among his victims. The pacer has been ruled out of the third and final England-Pakistan Test . Naseem has been ruled out of the second game at Multan after a shoulder injury and has not yet fully recovered. The 19-year-old will undergo further assessment at Lahoreâ€™s National High-Performance Centre, before beginning his recovery process, according to a press release by the Pakistan Cricket Board. newsArray.title: India vs Bangladesh: Allan Donald apologises to Dravid for 1997's 'ugly' spat, head coach responds
creator: FP Trending
newsArray.description: India vs Bangladesh: Allan Donald apologises to Dravid for 1997's 'ugly' spat, head coach responds
newsArray.content: Cricket Allan Donald apologises to Rahul Dravid for 'ugly' spat in 1997 series, India head coach responds While Allan Donald sought to apologise to Rahul Dravid for his on-field antics back in time, the Indian head coach was gracious and witty in his response. FP Trending December 15th, 2022 14:34:00 IST Rahul Dravid gave a hilarious reply to Allan Donald's apology. AP The first Test between India and Bangladesh is presently underway at Chattogram. But it seems like the fixture between the sides is also an opportunity for reconciliation. Bangladesh bowling coach Allan Donald has issued a public apology to India head coach Rahul Dravid for sledging him during an India vs South Africa ODI in 1997. Speaking to Sony Sports Network about the ongoing Test, Allan Donald recalled the sledging incident and admitted that he had â€œoverstepped the mark a little bitâ€ that day. He also invited Dravid for dinner. When the hosts asked Allan Donald about the 1997 sledging incident, the former pacer admitted that he had gone too far that day. Donald, who was famous for his comments to opposition batters, called the incident â€œuglyâ€ and said he did not wish to discuss it. â€œHe (Rahul Dravid) and Sachin were smoking us to all parts. I overstepped the mark a little bit. I just got nothing but massive respect for Rahul. I would like to go out and sit with Rahul and say sorry to him again about what happened back then. I just had to do something silly, that brought his wicket actually. But I still apologise for what I said that dayâ€, Donald said. Calling the former India skipper â€œa great blokeâ€ Donald said he would love to have a night out with Dravid. Separately, Dravid was also shown Donaldâ€™s apology and asked about it. The India coach was gracious in his reply and said he would definitely have dinner with Donald, especially if the former pacer was â€œpayingâ€. â€œAbsolutely yeah, absolutely, I look forward to it. Especially if heâ€™s paying.â€ Watch the video here: In the first India-Bangladesh Test, India decided to bat first after winning the toss and posted 404 on the scoreboard. Cheteshwar Pujara missed out on his century, after being dismissed on 90 by Taijul Islam. Shreyas Iyer had a similar fate and was dismissed for 86 off 192 to emerge as the second-highest scorer. For Bangladesh, Taijul Islam and Mehidy Hasan scalped 4 wickets each. Read all the Latest News , Trending News , Cricket News , Bollywood News , India News and Entertainment News here. newsArray.content: Chatogram: Indian all-rounder Ashwin scored a half-century in the first Test match against Bangladesh. Another quality innings came from his bat when the team was in dire straits. Ashwin, 36, will play his 87th Test match for India. Playing as the 8th batsman, he continues to contribute his best for the team. He has scored a total of 5 centuries in Test cricket. He has also registered 13 fifties. He has accumulated 442 wickets and 2,989 runs. In the match against Bangladesh, he scored 58 runs off 113 balls and lost his wicket. It included two fours and two sixes. He scored a half-century off 91 balls in this match. Mehdi Hasan lost his wicket on the bowling. Ashwin had put on a partnership of 87 runs with Kuldeep Yadav for the 8th wicket.

newsArray.title: Test Cricket: Kane Williamson Steps Down as New Zealand Test Skipper, Southee Named as Replacement
creator: Chanchal Bishwas
newsArray.description: Kane Williamson Steps Down as New Zealand Test Skipper, Southee Named as Replacement: Kane Williamson, who led New Zealand to the World Test Championship triumph in its inaugural edition, stepped down as captain from the longest format, the countryâ€™s cricket board announced on Thursday. New Zealandâ€™s pacer Tim Southee has been named the replacement in [â€¦] The post Test Cricket: Kane Williamson Steps Down as New Zealand Test Skipper, Southee Named as Replacement appeared first on KrookNews: Latest News, Sports News, Technology News, Gaming News.
newsArray.content: Kane Williamson Steps Down as New Zealand Test Skipper, Southee Named as Replacement: Kane Williamson, who led New Zealand to the World Test Championship triumph in its inaugural edition, stepped down as captain from the longest format, the countryâ€™s cricket board announced on Thursday. New Zealandâ€™s pacer Tim Southee has been named the replacement in their WTC title defense. Williamson will continue to lead the side in the white-ball format with a focus on the ODI World Cup in 2023 and T20 World Cup in 2024. Tom Latham has been appointed their vice-captain. â€œCaptaining the Black Caps in Test cricket has been an incredibly special honor,â€ said Williamson, who took over the role in 2016 from Brendon McCullum. â€œFor me, Test cricket is the pinnacle of the game and Iâ€™ve enjoyed the challenges of leading the side in the format.â€ Statistically, Williamson is the best Test captain in New Zealandâ€™s history, winning 22 of 40 matches at the helm, as well as eight draws and just 10 defeats. Read More | Big Bash League 2022: Teams, Squads, Live Streaming, Where to Watch Under his leadership, New Zealand reached the top of the Test rankings before emerging as winners of ICC Test Championship, beating India in the final in June last year. On his decision, Williamson said: â€œCaptaincy comes with an increased workload on and off the field and at this stage of my career I feel the time is right for this decision. â€œAfter discussions with NZC, we felt that continuing to captain the white-ball formats was preferable with two World Cups in the next two years.â€ Williamson said Southee and Latham will have him as a source of help throughout his tenure. â€œIâ€™m excited to support Tim as captain and Tom as vice-captain,â€ he said. â€œHaving played with both of them for most of my career, Iâ€™m confident theyâ€™ll do a great job.â€ Southee has 346 internationals to his name and has led the T20 side on 22 occasions. He will become New Zealandâ€™s 31st Test captain when he leads the team during this monthâ€™s Test tour to Pakistan. â€œItâ€™s been a surreal few days and itâ€™s just a massive honour to be appointed as Test captain,â€ Southee said. â€œI love Test cricket, itâ€™s the ultimate challenge and Iâ€™m really excited by the opportunity to lead the team in this format. â€œKaneâ€™s been an outstanding Test captain and Iâ€™m looking forward to working with Gary on how we can build on that,â€ he added. Read More | Virat Kohliâ€™s Emotional Message for Cristiano Ronaldo- â€˜You are, for me, the greatest of all timeâ€™ Paying his tribute to Williamson, New Zealand coach Gary Stead said: â€œKaneâ€™s guided the Test team through an immensely successful period which is a testament to his ability to bring people together and work towards a common goal. â€œHeâ€™s certainly led from the front with his own performances. He was very much the case during our push to win the World Test Championship. â€œThe Test team has continued to evolve and develop during his time. The fact weâ€™ve been able to introduce new players and see them thrive almost instantly is a credit to Kane and his leadership. â€œWe hope by lessening his workload we can continue to see the best of Kane Williamson for longer on the international stage, and we know he will remain a key leader in this group.â€ Sead said the decision to appoint Southee as captain came down to the direction in which the Test team wanted to head. â€œTimâ€™s a quality leader with a good cricket brain,â€ Stead said. â€œWeâ€™ve seen his captaincy skills on display with the T20 side. Iâ€™m sure heâ€™ll continue to bring an aggressive style. Whilst still maintaining the core fundamentals of how this Blackcaps team operates in the Test arena. â€œHe will also come from a slightly different perspective in being a bowler which Iâ€™m sure will also bring with it new ideas and fresh thinking.â€ Source Link

newsArray.title: NBL Covid threat still looms as blockbuster abandoned
newsArray.description: The threat of Covid wreaking havoc on the NBLâ€™s finals schedule remains real after the league was forced to postpone its first game of the season.
newsArray.content: In a flashback to the Covid issues of last season that affected every club, Friday eveningâ€™s clash between New Zealand and Perth was abandoned as coronavirus spread through the Breakersâ€™ squad.News Corp understands up to seven Breakers have contracted the virus, while three others, including French Next Star Rayan Rupert, are injured. Itâ€™s left the club unable to meet the leagueâ€™s minimum requirement of eight available players, hence the decision to reschedule the clash.Under the leagueâ€™s Covid policy, which apply to both regular season and finals games, decisions are made on a case-by-case basis. The first step is to postpone, second, reschedule and third and last resort, cancellation.It means a situation similar to the 2020 grand final, where lockdowns forced the premature end of the Sydney-Perth series, however unlikely, still looms.Watch every game live of the 2022/23 NBL Season on ESPN on Kayo Sports. New to Kayo? Start your free trial now >The Wildcats were up 2-1 in that series and the league made the controversial decision to award them the title, infuriating the Kings.After spending the best part of two seasons playing their games in Australia due to the pandemic, the Breakers have surged up the NBL ladder, currently in second place.While Australia has relaxed its Covid restrictions, New Zealand still requires those who test positive to isolate for seven days.Barring a huge form slump, itâ€™s left the NBL open to a potentially difficult task, should a similar situation arise with the Breakers during the finals, where logistics around playing dates, venue-availability and results of other games and seriesâ€™ take on added significance.But an NBL spokesperson viewed the postponement of the Breakers-Wildcats clash as a â€œminor setbackâ€.â€œThe Covid policy and rules remain in place for this season,â€ said.â€œWe will continue to work closely with clubs and all stakeholders when these situations occur.â€œThe league has enjoyed 74 uninterrupted games so far this season and views this particular situation as a minor setback.â€Breakers general manager Simon Edwards, on Thursday, said players were an hour away from leaving for the airport to fly to Perth when the decision was made.It comes as two Covid-positive Melbourne Stars players competed in cricketâ€™s Big Bash season opener with Sydney Thunder.Cricket has the luxury of a larger field and is a non-contact sport.Melbourne United coach Dean Vickerman, on Wednesday, said he hoped the virus reached a point where it was similar to a cold.â€œIâ€™m probably not comfortable (with) players from opposition or our team playing with Covid at this time,â€ Vickerman said.â€œIn time, when it gets to the point of â€˜hey, itâ€™s just a coldâ€™, and youâ€™re not going to pass it on to anyone â€” if we get to that point â€” Iâ€™ll be comfortable.â€Brisbane is scheduled to host the Breakers next. That clash is scheduled for Wednesday but the league is closely monitoring the unfolding situation.

newsArray.title: Cheteshwar Pujara, Shreyas Iyer carry India to 278/6 in First Test
creator: Sentinel Digital Desk
newsArray.description: In the first session, Bangladesh had taken out Shubman Gill, KL Rahul, and Virat Kohli to reduce India to 48/3 in 19.3 overs.
newsArray.content: CHATTOGRAM: Cheteshwar Pujara and Shreyas Iyer smashed half-centuries to lead India's recovery from 48/3 to 278/6 at stumps on day one of first Test against Bangladesh at the Zahur Ahmed Chowdhury Stadium, here on Wednesday.In the first session, Bangladesh had taken out Shubman Gill, KL Rahul, and Virat Kohli to reduce India to 48/3 in 19.3 overs. Pujara and Rishabh Pant (46) led the initial recovery for India through a counter-attacking 64-run stand. But once Pant fell in the second session, Pujara joined hands with Iyer to lead another rescue act for India through a solid 149-run stand for the fifth wicket. While Pujara was firm as a rock, Iyer was aggressive after a tentative start and had plenty of luck on his side. Though Pujara would fall ten runs short of his century as left-arm spinner Taijul Islam took him out to complete his three-wicket haul after beating him several times in the day, Iyer remained unbeaten on 82 off 169 balls on an absorbing day of Test cricket. Bangladesh, despite getting six wickets and Taijul being their standout bowler, would be wondering how the day would have been if they hadn't dropped Pujara and Iyer on 12 and 67 respectively. As Pant walked in to bat after being promoted to number five to counter Taijul, India were in trouble at 48/3 in 19.3 overs. His arrival brought a flurry of runs for India, through his trademark pull and sweep off the spinners. Brief Scores: India 278/6 in 90 overs (Cheteshwar Pujara 90, Shreyas Iyer 82 not out; Taijul Islam 3/84, Mehidy Hasan Miraz 2/71). newsArray.title: â€˜We needed the Kingâ€™: Warne made the BBL
newsArray.description: Melbourne Stars stand-in captain Adam Zampa has a â€œbit of Shane Warneâ€ in his leadership.
newsArray.content: So does injured Stars captain Glenn Maxwell according to coach Dave Hussey who played with the spin king in the early days of the Big Bash when it turned to Warne to give the competition the sort of star power only he could provide. Itâ€™s why Fridayâ€™s MCG clash against the Sydney Thunder, the first BBL game in front of the Shane Warne stand since the cricket legendâ€™s tragic passing, looms as an emotional for everyone who will put on a green shirt. Warne played 15 games for the Stars in the first two seasons of the BBL, after coming out of retirement to help kickstart the competition as its marquee man. Stars players will all wear Warneâ€™s No.23 on their playing shirts, before itâ€™s retired for good, which Maxwell said was the ultimate tribute to the clubâ€™s inaugural captain, who brought his significant â€œgiftsâ€ not just to the Melbourne team, but to a fledgling competition which he made everyone take notice of. â€œIn the first year of the BBL we needed the king and the BBL certainly needed him as well,â€ Maxwell said on Thursday. Warneâ€™s BBL stint was littered with magic and memorable moments including the night he talked through taking the wicket of New Zealand star Brendon McCullum, which Maxwell said showed the â€œgeniusâ€ he possessed. â€œNothing probably sort of show showcases the ability and skill and superstar power that he had like that moment,â€ he said. â€œIt just showed the genius of what he could do and to be able to take down the oppositionâ€˜s best player and talk you through it and take the fans to it, and be subject to ridicule if it doesnâ€™t go right. as well. â€œI think he had an incredible ability to bring life to any contest. And he did that in certainly different ways ... and he certainly paved the way for the rest of us to, I suppose have the things that we do now.â€Hussey was a foundation Stars player with Warne and said his capacity to take the entire game on his shoulders, to carry the burden of pressure, and thrive with a smile on his face, was significant to the emergence of the competition, and deserving of a tribute match. â€œItâ€™s hard to put into words because he was the star. The whole competition needed a star and we needed a leader and he came in and was both,â€ Hussey said. â€œWhat he did provide for us kids at the time is he took all the pressure of us and just told us pretty much how to play the game with no pressure on us which itâ€™s what Iâ€™m trying to do with our boys now.â€œWhen you play on the biggest stage in front of a big crowd at the MCG youâ€™re trying to take all the pressure off all the players so thatâ€™s what he provided for us and itâ€™s gonna be a nice fitting farewell just to celebrate his legacy.â€

newsArray.title: Narrative spins in David Warnerâ€™s favour but that is to forget the reasons behind his ban | Geoff Lemon
creator: Geoff Lemon
newsArray.description: The opener did what he did. He came back from it. And on the scale of hard done by, thereâ€™s barely a flickerOver a long career, David Warner has presented many versions of himself. The short-form bludgeoner of his T20 debut in 2009 gave way to the studious opener of his first Test century on a Hobart greentop in 2011. The raucous presence known as The Bull who was suspended from the 2013 Ashes gave way to the contemplative Reverend by 2015, schooling teammates on the power of positive thinking, before returning to his most confrontational mode before the Ashes in 2017. The instigator of the sandpaper ball-tampering plot in 2018 served a yearâ€™s playing ban, ran the well-worn path of public redemption via on-field success, and has since presented himself as an elder statesman with an accordingly impeccable disciplinary record.The way he is perceived has also shifted, in cricket media at least, but no shifts have been bigger than the last few weeks as his campaign to have his leadership ban overturned ran into a brick wall. Where his co-accused Steve Smith was banned from captaincy for two years, and Cameron Bancroft not at all, Warner was for life. And while he was in the gun in 2018, there is now broadly a consensus that his punishment was excessive, and the review process unfair. Continue reading...

newsArray.description: Mirabai Chanu: 'Winning World Championship medal tougher than Olympics'
newsArray.content: Kolkata: Star weightlifter Saikhom Mirabai Chanu added another feather to her cap earlier this month in Bogota when the 2020 Olympics silver medallist bagged a World Weightlifting Championships silver medal too in her favoured 49kg category.This was her second medal on the stage as she became a World Champion back in 2017 in the USA. But it wonâ€™t be wrong to say that the value of this silver is perhaps bigger than her 2017 triumph and may as well dwarf her Tokyo success too.Extremely humbled and grateful for this victory. Small step towards our eventual goal of an Olympic gold. Gratitude to my Coach Vijay sir, our President IWLF Sahdev Yadav sir, Sports Authority of India, all the stakeholders and well wishers. Will always make you proud ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡³ pic.twitter.com/eTBsmdTsXRâ€” Saikhom Mirabai Chanu (@mirabai_chanu) December 7, 2022And thatâ€™s down to the highly competitive field that the 28-year-old Indian athlete came up against two Chinese heavyweights in reigning Olympic Champion Hou Zhihui and three-time World Champion Jiang Huihua.The Olympics rule of allowing one lifter per nation meant Mirabai had a headache less in Tokyo.In 2017, none of the Chinese were there to worry her with the International Weightlifting Federationâ€™s ban on China among nine nations.â€œOlympics se World Championship tough hai (World Championship is tougher than Olympics),â€ Mirabai told Firstpost from her hometown Manipur on Wednesday. â€œYou are competing against 50 players in 49kg. From each nation there were two participants, especially China got their two best lifters too. Thatâ€™s why winning this medal was never going to be easy.â€Taking a look at the 49kg field on the global stage, Mirabai and the two Chinese are locked in a battle for supremacy with the Indian holding the clean and jerkâ€™s world record of 119kg. Zhihui (96kg; world record) and Huihua (94kg), on the other hand, are much stronger in the snatch category and have a better all-around game to often pip the Indian to the top.Aware of her rivalâ€™s strength, Mirabai knew she couldnâ€™t afford a slip-up in Bogota but resurfacing of her wrist injury tested her might further as she risked competing.â€œI was worried because my wrist pain was back while training in the USA (in St Louis, where she trained with national coach Vijay Sharma for two weeks to acclimatise to the local conditions) and thatâ€™s why in Colombia I was aiming not to pick more than 87kg in snatch,â€ she explained.However, a â€˜no liftâ€™ of her second attempt of 87kg forced Mirabai to re-attempt the lift and the Tokyo silver medallist stunned the crowd by salvaging a rare lift from a squat position.Shedding more light on her injury, coach Sharma said the injury resurfaced while training in the USA and upon consulting, their trusted strength and conditioning coach Dr. Aaron Horschig suggested that the elite athlete could compete without stretching herself.â€œAfter she complained of pain in her wrist it made me think we canâ€™t go to Bogota anymore,â€ said Sharma. â€œConsulting with Dr. Horschig revealed that small muscles in Miraâ€™s wrist are weak and it often gets injured but could compete if she doesnâ€™t push too hard.â€Trouble was waiting for Mirabai post her Colombia show as it was revealed that a lower back pain will keep her away from hard training for a month. Mirabai currently is back in her hometown in Manipur but will be soon at the national camp in Patiala with no time to waste.â€œI will be undergoing recovery from injury in Patiala and have not much time to waste as we have to start preparing for Asian Championships in May (an Olympic ranking tournament). I am not certain yet if I will go to the USA or other foreign camp for training,â€ said Mirabai before concluding.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

newsArray.title: Arjun Tendulkar on batting approach after maiden Ranji Trophy hundred: 'Grit it out then capitalise'
creator: Sahil Malhotra
newsArray.description: Arjun Tendulkar on batting approach after maiden Ranji Trophy hundred: 'Grit it out then capitalise'
newsArray.content: Before Wednesday, Arjun Tendulkar had not scored a hundred in any BCCI tournament. Be it age-group or senior cricket. The best he had managed, with the bat, was a 91 against Uttar Pradesh in a U-19 Cooch Behar Trophy fixture for Mumbai in the 2018-19 season. The 23-year-old finally got his moment under the sun when he scored his maiden First Class hundred against Rajasthan in the ongoing Ranji Trophy fixture in Porvorim.EXCLUSIVE | â€˜The knock has come against a good teamâ€™: Coach Subroto BanerjeeIn no time, he was all over social media and â€œlike father, like sonâ€ was the theme of most congratulatory posts. Just like the great Sachin Tendulkar, Arjun found his name in elite company when he completed the hundred on FC debut for Goa.Â View this post on InstagramÂ A post shared by Mumbai Indians (@mumbaiindians)The southpaw, moments after the dayâ€™s play got over, posted a video of his hundred celebration on Instagram with the caption â€œBUMPY ROADS HAVE THE BEST DESTINATIONS. MAIDEN 1st CLASS 100. #HARDWORKPAYSâ€. Sister Sara congratulated Arjun in a series of posts appreciating her brotherâ€™s efforts in the middle.It wasnâ€™t smooth sailing for Arjun as he walked out to bat in a difficult situation. The first job at hand was to see off the remaining overs of the dayâ€™s play and â€œprotectâ€ a well-set Suyash Prabhudesai who was battling well past fifty at that stage. The left-hander performed the night-watchmanâ€™s role to perfection and ensured there were no more casualties when stumps were called on the opening day.â€œWhen I first walked out to bat I had to face most of the balls because Suyash was batting on 80 so it was my job to protect him and play most of the balls,â€ Arjun told reporters after play ended on Day 2.The opening session of the second day was all about â€œgiving the first hour to the bowlersâ€.â€œAs of the approach today, it was more about the basics. Just give first hour to the bowlers. After we grit the initial phase out, itâ€™s time to capitalise. And time to get runs. As I said, it was the new ball and the new ball would do something. I honestly donâ€™t care how I look, I gritted the first difficult phase out and then I cashed in,â€ said Arjun.Â View this post on InstagramÂ A post shared by Arjun Tendulkar (@arjuntendulkar24)Was he aware about his father also scoring a hundred on First Class debut? â€œNo I wasnâ€™t aware,â€ came the quick reply.For years now, Arjun â€” the bowler â€” has hogged most of the limelight and his skills with the bat have rather gone unnoticed. But for the left-hander, he always had belief in his batting abilities and informs that the hundreds have been scored in trial matches for the Mumbai Cricket Association during age-group days.â€œI always had belief in my ability and wanted to just get set, and once I am set itâ€™s about cashing in and getting the big runs. As I said, just play the first hour out and capitalise,â€ said Arjun.Arjun is off to a fine start in the First Class circuit but the youngster is not keen to look too far ahead and wants to focus on staying in the present and winning the ongoing match against Rajasthan.â€œJust play each game and each ball on the merit. For now, just try winning this game,â€ said Arjun.With Prabhudesai, who scored 212, Arjun put on a brilliant partnership and the left-right combination clearly frustrated a very potent Rajasthan attack on the second day. The duo put on 221 runs and more importantly were out in the middle for over 60 overs. The solid stand ended when Kamlesh Nagarkoti dismissed Arjun for 120. At the end of dayâ€™s play, Arjun spoke about the partnership and lavished praise on Prabhudesai.â€œIt was great help (batting with Prabhudesai). He was batting well and showing good character. Had tightened his defence and was leaving the ball well. I kept talking to him and it was great help in the middle,â€ said Arjun.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

newsArray.title: Canes spearhead to unleash new tricks
newsArray.description: IMPORT tweaker Shadab Khan will bring some magic, but Hurricanes strike weapon Nathan Ellis has forecast he will have more tricks up his sleeve this season.
newsArray.content: Ellis, who was this week named vice captain alongside Ben McDermott under skipper Matthew Wade, has forged a reputation as a death bowling weapon with his yorkers and slower balls.The 28-year-old has played two seasons of IPL and knows he needs to continue to enhance his options as Hobart begins its season against Melbourne Stars at the MCG on Friday.â€œIâ€™ve got a couple (of new variations) Iâ€™m not ready to divulge,â€ he said.â€œItâ€™s an ever evolving games and Iâ€™m very much aware now Iâ€™m not the new kid on the block any more. â€œThereâ€™s a lot of video players can watch to be ready, so Iâ€™m trying to be proactive and its very important to keep learning new tricks.â€Ellis was considered unlucky by many to be overlooked for the T20 World Cup after taking 15 wickets at an average of 8.53 and an economy rate of 6.40 in five appearances for Australia. Although a return to the green and gold provides motivation, he insisted he didnâ€™t feel hard by missing out to the likes of Pat Cummins, Mitchell Starc and Josh Hazelwood. â€œThe guys who do get picked, the â€˜big threeâ€™ as theyâ€™re called, I still picture them as out of this world and players I really look up to,â€ he said.â€œTo be spoken about alongside them is really cool. But Iâ€™m really aware youâ€™re owed no favours to the Australia jersey and the fact Iâ€™ve played a handful of games Iâ€™m really stoked with. â€œIf more opportunity comes thatâ€™d be amazing. Everyone wants to play for Australia, thatâ€™s what we do this for and dreamt of growing up.â€œObviously you want to play, but if it doesnâ€™t (happen) Iâ€™ll do my best for the purple.â€Ellis doesnâ€™t feel his role will change dramatically as vice captain, aside from the fact heâ€™s the only bowler of the leadership trio. â€œItâ€™s a massive (honour). Itâ€™s my first time in a leadership role and in a way I still feel new to the game myself,â€ he said.â€œWhen youâ€™ve got someone like Matthew Wade in our team, mine and Benâ€™s roles ownâ€™t be enormous, just another voice if he needs it,â€ he said.â€œIâ€™ll try and bring those experiences Iâ€™ve had on and off the field to the new guys.â€œI feel like that can be one of my assets (guiding the bowlers). Iâ€™ve been in pressure situations in tense games, so thatâ€™s something Iâ€™m willing to do. â€œWith Wade wicketkeeping, having another voice closer to the bowler is a great opportunity for Ben and I to dip our toe in the water.â€Ellis is excited about the variation Pakistan international leg spinner Khan can bring to the bowling line-up, as well as his all-round game. â€œAny T20 side who wants to compete needs to have a wickettaking spinner,â€ Ellis said. â€œShadab is exactly that, but heâ€™s also one of the best fielders in the world and smacks the ball in the top or middle order.â€Fast bowling recruit Billy Stanlake was left out of the 13-man squad to play the Stars as he nears a return from stress fractures in his back, but made his premier cricket debut with Greater Northern Raiders on Saturday.HURRICANES SQUAD TO PLAY STARS: FRIDAY, 5.05PM - Asif Ali, Tim David, Paddy Dooley, Nathan Ellis (vc), Caleb Jewell, Shadab Khan, Ben McDermott (vc), Riley Meredith, Jimmy Neesham, Joel Paris, Dâ€™Arcy Short, Chris Tremain, Matthew Wade (c)

newsArray.title: Kane Williamson steps down as NZ Test skipper
creator: Post News Network
newsArray.description: Auckland: Kane Williamson, who led New Zealand to the World Test Championship triumph in its inaugural edition, stepped down as captain from the longest format, the countryâ€™s cricket board announced Thursday. Tim Southee has been named the replacement in their WTC title defence. Williamson will continue to lead the side in the white-ball format with [â€¦]
newsArray.content: Kane Williamson steps down as NZ Test skipper PTI Updated: December 15th, 2022, 10:32 IST in Sports 0 Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on WhatsApp Share on Linkedin Auckland: Kane Williamson, who led New Zealand to the World Test Championship triumph in its inaugural edition, stepped down as captain from the longest format, the countryâ€™s cricket board announced Thursday. Tim Southee has been named the replacement in their WTC title defence. Williamson will continue to lead the side in the white-ball format with focus on the ODI World Cup in 2023 and T20 World Cup in 2024. Tom Latham has been appointed their vice-captain. â€œCaptaining the Black Caps in Test cricket has been an incredibly special honour,â€ said Williamson, who took over the role in 2016 from Brendon McCullum. â€œFor me, Test cricket is the pinnacle of the game and Iâ€™ve enjoyed the challenges of leading the side in the format.â€ Statistically, Williamson is the best Test captain in New Zealandâ€™s history, winning 22 of 40 matches at the helm, as well as eight draws and just 10 defeats. Under his leadership, New Zealand reached the top of the Test rankings before emerging as winners of the ICC Test Championship, beating India in the final in June last year. On his decision, Williamson said: â€œCaptaincy comes with an increased workload on and off the field and at this stage of my career I feel the time is right for this decision. â€œAfter discussions with NZC, we felt that continuing to captain the white-ball formats was preferable with two World Cups in the next two years.â€ Williamson said Southee and Latham will have him as a source of help throughout his tenure. â€œIâ€™m excited to support Tim as captain and Tom as vice-captain,â€ he said. â€œHaving played with both of them for most of my career, Iâ€™m confident theyâ€™ll do a great job.â€ Southee, who has 346 internationals to his name and has led the T20 side on 22 occasions, will become New Zealandâ€™s 31st Test captain when he leads the team during this monthâ€™s Test tour to Pakistan. The first Test begins on Boxing Day in Karachi. â€œItâ€™s been a surreal few days and itâ€™s just a massive honour to be appointed as Test captain,â€ Southee said. â€œI love Test cricket, itâ€™s the ultimate challenge and Iâ€™m really excited by the opportunity to lead the team in this format. â€œKaneâ€™s been an outstanding Test captain and Iâ€™m looking forward to working with Gary on how we can build on that,â€ he added. Paying his tribute to Williamson, New Zealand coach Gary Stead said: â€œKaneâ€™s guided the Test team through an immensely successful period which is a testament to his ability to bring people together and work towards a common goal. â€œHeâ€™s certainly led from the front with his own performances and that was very much the case during our push to win the World Test Championship. â€œThe Test team has continued to evolve and develop during his time and the fact weâ€™ve been able to introduce new players and see them thrive almost instantly is a credit to Kane and his leadership. â€œWe hope by lessening his workload we can continue to see the best of Kane Williamson for longer on the international stage, and we know he will remain a key leader in this group.â€ Sead said the decision to appoint Southee as captain came down to the direction in which the Test team wanted to head. â€œTimâ€™s a quality leader with a good cricket brain,â€ Stead said. â€œWeâ€™ve seen his captaincy skills on display with the T20 side and Iâ€™m sure heâ€™ll continue to bring an aggressive style, whilst still maintaining the core fundamentals of how this Blackcaps team operates in the Test arena. â€œHe will also come from a slightly different perspective in being a bowler which Iâ€™m sure will also bring with it new ideas and fresh thinking.â€ Tags: kane williamson Tim Southee World Test Championship Share Tweet Send Share Suggest A Correction Enter your email to get our daily news in your inbox. newsArray.title: Starc reveals his sadness, regret over Warne dispute
newsArray.description: Mitchell Starc has revealed his sadness that he never got to break bread with Shane Warne and reconcile the relentless criticism he copped from the Spin King.
newsArray.content: Warneâ€™s annual critiques of Starcâ€™s form and body language served as both a blessing and a curse, because while the motivation helped drive him to the entrance door of one of cricketâ€™s most elite clubs, the narrative for many years took away from the fact the left-armer was on a trajectory to go down as an all-time great.In the months before he tragically died earlier this year of a heart attack, Warne told News Corp in an interview that his criticism of Starc was not personal and that he would like to catch up with him to discuss over a beer.Starc on Thursday lamented never getting that chance, as he prepares for the first Test against South Africa at the Gabba, only four wickets away from the coveted milestone of 300 Test wickets.â€œThatâ€™s part of the evolution. Learning to let things go,â€ said Starc.â€œThe disappointing part or the sad part is that we never got to have that conversation. I guess weâ€™ll never know (whether it was personal).â€œI donâ€™t know â€“ I never got a phone call to take up that offer (of a beer).â€œHindsight is a wonderful thing.â€It was at the Gabba in 2014 when Warne first caused a stir when he described Starcâ€™s body language as â€œsoftâ€ on a sweltering hot day in Brisbane when conditions were oppressive for fast bowlers.Starcâ€™s camp felt Warne unfairly targeted the quick from that moment on, and even on the eve of last summer, the spin king boldly declared on Fox Cricket Australia should drop the left-armer for the first Ashes Test.Warneâ€™s manager James Erskine revealed on Fox Cricket the day of Warneâ€™s death that the cricketing legend had privately acknowledged that he was wrong in his harsh assessment of Starc last summer, after the fast bowling ace dominated England in the first three Tests, including a wicket from the first ball of the series.In an interview with News Corp before his death, Warne insisted he would have happily sat down for a â€œbeerâ€ with Starc, and hoped that his at times stinging commentary had served as some motivation, even if the big quick didnâ€™t appreciate what was being said.â€œI have no issue whatsoever. Itâ€™s not personal. If Mitchell Starc wants to talk about anything Iâ€™m happy to talk to him too. If he wants to have a beer and have a chat about stuff, Iâ€™ll say, â€˜Mitch, mate, happy to chat,â€™â€ Warne told News Corp in an unpublished interview from last summer.â€œItâ€™s nothing personal. Iâ€™m there to judge what I see â€¦ It devalues the public out there (if you donâ€™t give) your opinion. It looks like youâ€™re having favourites.â€œUnfortunately, Iâ€™ve got an opinion and I think itâ€™s important that us commentators, or people in the game, yourself (journalists) included, youâ€™ve got to be honest with your opinions and some people arenâ€™t going to like it, which is fine.â€œBut maybe they might respect it, or maybe it might even inspire them. Who knows?â€œThey might say; â€˜Iâ€™ll show you.â€™ Thatâ€™s good too.â€For years, that was Starcâ€™s attitude. But eventually he realised it was wearing him down carrying a chip on his shoulder, and over the past four years he has adopted a different, more mellow approach which has coincided with him finding the best form of his career as he prepares to reach a 300-milestone that history says is the most accurate marker for what constitutes a bowling great.â€œI did (use criticism as motivation) with everything. I was someone who listened to and read everything,â€ Starc said.â€œAnd then that year (2018-19) we had multiple broadcasters start, everyone coming in with radio and whatever, thatâ€™s when it really doubled down on the noise and it really got away from (me).â€œThatâ€™s where I learnt best to let things go and only worry about the groups that mattered most to me and those closest to me. Thatâ€™s all I need to feel comfortable in myself. That was a point where it changed a fair bit for me, where I chose not to read things and itâ€™s continued on where it doesnâ€™t matter.â€œI donâ€™t pay attention to a lot of stuff which has made a huge difference.â€œItâ€™s part of cricket. Youâ€™re going to have your critics and everyone is entitled to have an opinion. Iâ€™ll just keep going about my cricket.â€

New Zealand Cricket announced that he has withdrawn as the Test series against Pakistan is to be played. The 32-year-old Kane Williamson took over the [â€¦]
newsArray.content: Wellington: Kane Williamson has stepped down as the captain of the New Zealand Test cricket team. It is reported that he will continue to lead the ODI and T20 teams. New Zealand Cricket announced that he has withdrawn as the Test series against Pakistan is to be played. The 32-year-old Kane Williamson took over the captaincy for all formats in 2016. The New Zealand team under his leadership was performing well. His team won the 2021 ICC World Test Championship. In this case, he is out of the Test series. New Zealand will tour Pakistan for Test and ODI series. Veteran Tim Southee will act as the captain of the team in this series. Williamson will continue to lead the ODI and T20 teams, according to New Zealand Cricket. It is reported that Tom Latham will act as the vice-captain of the team. BLACKCAPS @BLACKCAPS Kane Williamson will step down as captain of the BLACKCAPS Test side, with Tim Southee to take up the leadership mantle. Tom Latham has been confirmed as Test vice-captain, after previously leading the side in Williamsonâ€™s absence. #CricketNation https://t.co/D9rPWUl05d 4:23 PM Â· Dec 14, 2022 1.1K 154

newsArray.description: It was one of the darkest days in Australian cricket, but Usman Khawaja says the players have moved past what happened in South Africa four years ago.
